Comment:
Maths, which I hated with a vengeance! Mind you being dyslexic, even though I had a good memory, I had problems learning enough to come away with any qualifications, but I did manage to get a job as a private Nanny, which lead to more roles within child care, which lasted for just over 13 years, even after getting married and having my first child.
Then after the birth of my second child, I took up volunteering for charities, as retail assistant and now my dream is to eventually open up my own secondhand and vintage shop.

I think that all subjects are needed to form a comprehensively developed person. Mathematics is important, but not for everyone. I think it is more given to people with a different mindset.
 We can also say about languages, biology, chemistry, political science, history, ecology, that are well received by other children.
But I would like to keep your attention to the following aspect.
Education and formation of a person. Society needs decent,kind, well-mannered people.
Those who understand the values of life, relationships between people, care, love of humanity, respect, politeness. It is necessary to be kind in order to raise a good generation. In addition, I would add ethics and behavior, culture and art. In the future, the children themselves will choose which science is closer to them and what they want deepen.There may be classes with advanced study of math.But of course, if you can create methods and mechanisms for better understanding and development, then why not?

I’m 66 and still using my fingers to count!  Not interested in percentages and as my multiplication tables long gone off my memory. But still having fun about it all and let the machines do it all for me. Worth learning 5 languages to get me around the world and history is just magical to have learnt. Even the religions are great to know a little to be able to respect them. 
Bill can I use your playlist with my 3 years old granddaughter?  I may learn something myself too
Definitely Math🤓✌️ Everything that can be counted, doesn’t always count and Everything that counts .. insn’t always counted. 🤨🥱🤓

Math could of focused more on daily life and the costs of everything. They should have 3 or more stages for that if kids want to deepen their math skills. I loved science. English could be mixed with spanish or another language at an earlier time because being young your mind absorb like a sponge. History could of been better by doing a family history so you can talk about that era and it would peek most kids interests. So many levels in that too that could of been covered.
Do you like my Infinity concept in geometry?

The particularly difficult one was a Chronological order question. 5-6 events would be given jumbled up and we had to remember the dates and put them in the right order. In lower grades the events would be spaced out... but as we went into higher grades the event timings would keep getting closer and closer and create confusion...
It is one thing to know that something happened approximately 1000 years back, but it is entirely a different topic to exactly say whether the event happened 1001 years & 1 month earlier or 999 years & 7 months earlier... Bring in the date and it's an entirely different fudge altogether...

None! I was good at everything! I was known as an All-Rounder! But I am really struggling at A-LEVEL Google Maps! 😉❗I was good at ballet, sport, all Academic subject disciplines, dance, swimming, singing in the school choir, I was the reason my tutor group in Secondary School won Sports' Day 3 Years in a row and make up my own jokes which make even my mum laugh and giggle, more whitty than GOSH. And loved winding up my GCSE English Teacher;- like I am doing rite now and even did 3 Days' Women's Self Defence Class rather than grading in the martial arts' Class that NO woman or girl would turn up to and I soon (after a year) after realised why! 😎! Made my Career Choice very difficult. PERSONALITY Wise think of me more Macro-Hard than Micro-Soft.

To answer your question from the given four selections, ‘History’ is the subject I am choosing.

The preface to this choice is very interesting for me.  It was not a subject I studied during schooling.  However, I am a very big enthusiast into History overall by reading, listening, viewing and evaluating selective topics that interest me.

I recommend the Book by Mr. Yuval Noah Harari-
‘Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind’.
for all to review and would further my recommendation that it would be an excellent item presented in schools.  

Kind regards,

If math's the challenge, your 'By the Numbers' Spotify playlist might be the remedy. Music has a magical way of making things more enjoyable. As for my least favourite subject in school, well, I'm all about learning, so no subjects are on my dislike list.

Sweet playlist! Math getting a groove-up sounds like a plan. As for school, I admit I wasn't there, but if I had a least favourite subject, it would probably be "Waiting for Quantum Computers 101." That class takes forever! 😄🎶 #ByTheNumbers #QuantumBeats

English by a long shot. I do not enjoy the physical act of writing. I had a teacher that made us write everything out by hand so she could recognize the handwriting and could ensure someone else didn’t write it. All the other classes allowed use of my word processor and those classes were much more tolerable.

I love history now but when I was a kid it felt it was unfair since so much happened from the beginning of time until then. Even kids 2000 years ago didn’t have to learn about Greek society or European wars. Thousands of years and something’s important happening every year all over the world. It was just too much to store in my little brain.
Answer: Religion! (Hocus Pocus fairytales created by superstitious, uneducated and  non-scientific people thousands of years ago, with no facts and figures to prove any of it to be true)
History, mostly due the way they taught the subject back in the days. Now, it’s a favorite 🙂

I found History my best and worst subject! See history is based on point of view, and let me tell you, if your a reader like I was growing up, you realized what they we teaching us in those history books was skewed to a particular narrative! 

I became a teacher and have a composite Social Studies teaching certification from Texas! My kids (students) always loved it when we talked the rise and fall of civilization and my first question to them always was? How did their toilets work? What type of plumbing did they have? And so many more questions about how society grew, not who and what year did they exist! 
It was more about the engineering of society, not the history! 
Today’s education misses the mark, the math does not add up, and the barritives change daily! But for one moment in time I taught the rise and the fall, and it was not about the power play in history, it was more about the how they designed how to live!
PE

🦈 Hey Bill Gates 🦈,
David the Shark here 🦈! Surfing through the digital waves, I couldn't help but chomp on your 'By the Numbers' playlist. Music and math, what a fintastic combo! 🎵➕🔢
Speaking of school subjects, history was my least favorite, but not for the reasons most might think. In my JHS, I was told that the USA won the 1776 war because the British soldiers just stood there and got shot. They said that's how wars were fought back then - line up on opposite sides and shoot. I mean, come on! 🤦‍♂️🦈 That's like saying sharks only swim in straight lines. We all know there's more depth to history, just as there's more to the ocean's currents.
It's essential to teach history accurately, just as it's crucial to make subjects like math engaging. Thanks for doing your part with that groovy playlist! 🎶
Keep making waves, Bill! And remember, history might be written by the victors, but it's up to us to ensure it's told correctly.
Spread Shark Love #GabenFreUde 🦈❤️ #divineintervention. Fun fact: Did you know sharks have been around for over 400 million years, witnessing history unfold beneath the waves? Talk about a deep dive into the past! 🦈🌊📜

Well as to the contrary opinion. My worst subject was English. Reason being that learning started from  a strong vernacular background on which you had to understand concepts from the mother tongue. Unfortunately as I grew through classes things changed that I had to learn English to understand all the subjects. 
Maths became difficult because of English or I had to transillitrate questions to the native language to understand it. Anyway every subject is easy but it depends with the teacher, language, environment, time of introduction.
The worst was fear and terror unleashed by the teacher should you get the answer wrong. Many strokes Infront of you fellow pupils as you cry all your tears while others laugh at you.
All these frustrations demoralized me and hated maths. Am sorry it was a nightmare.

I never understand why history is still more important subject than computer in school.. (atleast in India i have seen)… where history can change based on which government rule.. based on country.. means think how british are teaching about how they ruled India India and how we taught British ruled.. history should not be a long theoretical language but better a presentation language.. taught history using VR technology.. by the way .. that you can teach using math also like trigonometry calculations using AR technology.. or physics.. but still History.. as i know western countries has different teaching techniques.. In India kids studied books as seriously since LKG

Mathematics provides an effective way of building mental discipline and encourages logical reasoning and mental rigor. In addition, mathematical knowledge plays a crucial role in understanding the contents of other school subjects such as science, social studies, and even music and art.

Science instils a sense of intrigue and enables students to develop understanding and form questions based both on the knowledge they already have and the insight they wish to gain in the future. Students who excel in science lessons are likely to develop a strong ability to think critically.

English is important for students as it broadens their minds, develops emotional skills, improve the quality of life by providing job opportunities. Moreover, the use of English as an International language is growing with time because it is the only medium for communication in many countries.

Because history gives us the tools to analyze and explain problems in the past, it positions us to see patterns that might otherwise be invisible in the present – thus providing a crucial perspective for understanding (and solving!) current and future problems.

I was very good at English but regrettably i didn't like Shakespeare whatsoever . H.G Wells ,  Charles Dickens & John Keats are the real Aces in my opinion. I detested science,  but that was partly due to a ghastly teacher insulting me. He who is quite legendary in Sandwich . Portly children, short or small children were picked on in the same manner with verbal bullying  insults. Today there would a legal challenge made for sure . Lucky he retired then isn't it. Time is also a great healer in cases like these.
I am not mistaken because he picked on my wonderful wife some twelve years later . Helen is big , beautiful & clever , she also attained a double A in science  . Yet was often called S***.
How difficult it is then ,when one has ADHD & Dyxlexia to take on  the pains that are Algebra, Equation & Logarithm. Arithmetic was generally easy up until that point .I humiliated myself by copying figures from my old pal Mike Burch  who was very proficient , helpful & hardworking . However this was done in a hurried muddled confusion just to keep- up some kind of make believe  momentum. 
Sadly & not surprisingly it made no difference whatsoever & perhaps its the most just conclusion in this instance & in this particular case . ©️

As an educated guess, it will be Math for most. But even Mathematics can be written 'poetically', albeit highly dependent on good influencers if it makes you spend a reasonable amount of time enjoying learning it. Looking back on my academic journey, none of the list was my least favorite subject. I even really liked Sports, especially athletics and football.

There are many ways to help someone understand math. The outcome is always the same, no matter what technique you use to get to the answer, if the person clicks with it, they will arrive at the same ability as everyone else that can do that particular type of math, and the same answers to the curriculum's tests. Creativity is not punished if the student finds a unique but ultimately correct way of getting to the answer.

Short of copying someone else's work, you'll never have two people answer the same for the majority of what is taught in English. So how do you coach or teach such a subjective subject without killing creativity? Who here remembers what happened to the students who disagreed that Romeo & Juliet was a tragedy?  English --  A subjective subject that seems to have only one narrow range of correct answers based mostly on who's teaching it. There's got to be a better way!

Going by this list...my best was #Maths; second best was #Sciences(Physics, Chemistry, Biology); third best was #English......I ended up as an #Economist.

How it affected my Children 
My Three Children all Girls...The First yob:2004 [still undergraduate in BSc(Electrical Electronics)]....The second yob:2007[fresh undergraduate in MBBS(Medicine & Surgery)]....My last daughter yob:2008 planning to enter University next year for BPharm(Pharmacy)]

yob = year of birth.

One thing I found frustrating about math, especially after 6th grade, is that what we were learning seemed to have less and less practical application. It was more akin to puzzle-solving than to anything with real-world practical applications. This continued through my undergraduate years. The lone and notable exception was in my statistics and data analysis education (shout out to Harold Stolper), which has virtually limitless applications and requires the development of broader critical thinking skills.

If I had my way, statistics would be more heavily emphasized in American mathematics education.

Math was tough on me !! and is tough on my son too. !!!!!!!! 
However, given the technology landscape and the ever increasingly exposure to AI, I increasingly understand the need for a strong math foundation. I spend multiple hours every week to explain to my son as to how math is useful to us in our daily life and how we use them unknowingly.
I enjoy Learning Math Again, though I don't remember when I unlearnt it, possibly because I dint learn it t right way.
But trust me, Math is giving me a Second chance !!, and am doing well !!!, learning it along with my Son, and this time, learning it the right way, by understanding it and knowing the applications of it.

Folks, I have an idea to help engage our youth and young adults.  It is a bit different and will take some time… ODYSSEY:  A COMMUNITY LEVEL YOUTH ENGAGEMENT ARCHITECTURE (ResearchGate.net) and in my profile here, is an idea to have a semi-automated program ‘host’ other programs and educational events that engage youth.  It does so by hiring our community’s professionals, craftsmen, artisans, and educators as part-time contractors to offer short exciting and engaging educational events based on their expertise.  Take a look, let me know what questions you have.  Let’s get started in our efforts to build safe and engaging communities.  We can build a future worth looking forward to.

Math often becomes boring when many math teachers solely focus on teaching the mechanics of math without providing real-life examples for context. Similarly, history can also be dull without proper contextualization. The human brain is inherently wired to understand information within a relevant context. This emphasizes the significance of teacher training, rather than attributing students’ lack of interest or understanding to the subject matter itself.
